data.title: 'Were you born stupid or did you work at it?': Stephen King's exchange with climate change denier goes viral
data.meta_description: Nick Adams' war of words with Stephen King snowballed into a controversy, with several people coming out in support of the iconic writer
data.text:
Climate change has become a byword in our lives, but some individuals still persist in denying its existence. Many people over the globe still deny the idea of strange weather events being exacerbated by climate change. One of these climate change deniers recently got schooled by author Stephen King on Twitter. The chat has grabbed eyeballs, with social media users lauding King for taking on the issue with his trademark wit. The dispute began when Nick Adams, political commentator and climate change denier, dropped a video of snowfall in Los Angeles and made a comment about global warming.

Advertisement

âThis is near Los Angeles. Where is your global warming now, liberals?â wrote Adams while sharing the video. The clip shows snow falling in Los Angeles while people go about their daily lives. Some individuals can be seen filming the snow around them.

Check the tweet here:

Adamsâ tweet prompted a lot of reactions. Author Stephen King wrote, âWere you born stupid or did you work at it?â

Advertisement

Adams shot back with a criticism of the writerâs books. âYour books are shit. Try writing something real America cares about,â he replied.

Advertisement

Needless to say, Adams’ war of words with Stephen King snowballed into a controversy, with several people coming out in support of the iconic writer. âAnother first grader response to one of the biggest best-selling authors in the world,â one user wrote.

Advertisement

Advertisement

âââ¦that America cares about.â Bro, Stephen Kingâs The Shining sold 700,000 copies and was adapted into a movie that grossed nearly $50 million at the box office. Sure, buddy, Americans donât care about himâ, another user sarcastically quipped.

Advertisement

Advertisement

âEveryone knows King’s works. Most people have never heard of your books. No one will remember them, since they won’t get reprints. While King will be remembered for decades and maybe centuries, no one will ever recall youâ, one individual reminded Adams.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Several users were also critical of Adamâs views on climate change. âTell me you donât know science without saying you donât know science,â one person joked.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Another said that Adams had just proved the very thing he was trying to mock.

Los Angeles and parts of southern California faced a rare snowstorm last week. The National Weather Service called it one of the strongest storms to hit the state, as per an Associated Press report.
